head.title: Why DHEA Isn't Banned: A View From the Senate

hedline.hl1: Why DHEA Isn't Banned: A View From the Senate

block.p: You call on Congress to re-examine its decision to allow the marketing of DHEA, a natural anti-aging supplement that has been safely marketed for decades (''Muscle Flexing in Congress,'' editorial, April 20).
You did not mention one critical fact: Congress has already given the Drug Enforcement Administration the authority to schedule DHEA as a controlled substance.

You call on Congress to re-examine its decision to allow the marketing of DHEA, a natural anti-aging supplement that has been safely marketed for decades (''Muscle Flexing in Congress,'' editorial, April 20).
You did not mention one critical fact: Congress has already given the Drug Enforcement Administration the authority to schedule DHEA as a controlled substance.
The same law that exempted DHEA based on its past history of beneficial use -- and lack of evidence of abuse -- also changed the criteria for adding to the controlled-substances list.

Senator Joseph R. Biden, the law's lead sponsor, and I also agreed that if DHEA becomes an abuse problem and the D.E.A. fails to use this authority, we would change the law to protect the public health.
We agreed that Congress should not restrict access to a product that has given health and vigor to millions. Instead, we should monitor its use and act promptly if the need arises.
Orrin G. Hatch U.S. Senator from Utah Washington, April 25, 2005
